item.text: This program only makes sense, if you use keystrokes! Here is a list:

textXML.div: This program only makes sense, if you use keystrokes! Here is a list:

item.creator: maxrohde

item.text:
alt + down: insert a new item after select item
ctrl + up: select previous item
ctrl + down: select following item/ create one if none existent
ctrl + alt + right: create a new document and link it with currently selected item (action also known als Linnk! ;)
ctrl + alt + left: creates a list with currently selected item as heading
ctrl + right: goes to document which is linked with currently selected item
ctrl + left: show previously viewed document
ctrl + alt + up: move currently selected item up
ctrl + alt + down: move currently selected item down

textXML.div:
alt + down: insert a new item after select item
ctrl + up: select previous item
ctrl + down: select following item/ create one if none existent
ctrl + alt + right: create a new document and link it with currently selected item (action also known als Linnk! ;)
ctrl + alt + left: creates a list with currently selected item as heading
ctrl + right: goes to document which is linked with currently selected item
ctrl + left: show previously viewed document
ctrl + alt + up: move currently selected item up
ctrl + alt + down: move currently selected item down

item.creator: maxrohde

item.text: Feel free to play around on this document with them.

textXML.div: Feel free to play around on this document with them.

item.creator: maxrohde

item.text:
I recommend that you put all your data under ONE root document. Create this by Menu File / New Document. Choose a place that you can easily backup - for instance under your ~/Documents directory.
You will not need the "New Document" function afterwards. Create new documents by inserting text items to your root document and linking them with ctrl + alt + left with a newly created document.

textXML.div:
I recommend that you put all your data under ONE root document. Create this by Menu File / New Document. Choose a place that you can easily backup - for instance under your ~/Documents directory.
You will not need the "New Document" function afterwards. Create new documents by inserting text items to your root document and linking them with ctrl + alt + left with a newly created document.
